item.title: Brown sets out anti-recession plan of tax credits and rate cuts
item.description: Gordon Brown on Friday heralded an anti-recession strategy founded on tax cuts for low earners and further cuts in interest rates, in the hope that Britain will spend its way out of the downturn

item.title: Brown warns on protectionism
item.description: Gordon Brown warned that the UK government's bail-out of banks would not be extended to other ailing industries during the recession, as he denounced protectionism as 'the road to ruin'

item.title: Brown calls for 'urgent' global stimulus
item.description: The British prime minister urges leading countries to reflate the world economy as he holds talks with top economists in New York, including Nobel prize winner Paul Krugman

item.title: Tourism drop sparks call for marketing boost
item.description: Industry leaders call for government action to help promote UK destinations after visitor numbers fall sharply during what is usually the busiest time of the year

item.title: Iceland sees red over RAF mission
item.description: Reykjavik politicians and members of the public see the prospect of UK jets flying over them as unthinkable after Britain used an anti-terror act to freeze some of the island's bank assets

item.title: Commerce beats politics in rescue of banks
item.description: The 'fudge-free' mandate of UK Financial Investments, the state-owned company looking after taxpayers' interests, seems to conflict with the initial presentation of the £37bn bail-out to parliament

item.title: Tender axed to save Post Office card
item.description: The Post Office was awarded a £1bn five-year contract to retain its benefits card account, after ministers axed a procurement process that in March put the business out to competitive tender

item.title: Britons against troop surge in Afghanistan
item.description: BBC poll shows that 68% of Britons want the UK to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan within 12 months, but the defence ministry says its own survey shows that 50% support the mission

item.title: Pension reform plan worries unions
item.description: Opinion divided over the government's decision to review a rule where restructuring firms should put in enough cash to protect promised retirement benefits

item.title: The Bank rethinks importance of house prices
item.description: The Bank of England appears in its November inflation report to reassess the significance of house prices for the economy and its role in consumption, particularly as collateral for bank borrowings

item.title: FSA lowers customer fairness bar
item.description: The City watchdog is folding the long-running TCF initiative into normal prudential supervisory visits – a move that will save it what it admitted was 'resource intensive' work

item.title: Moves afoot to halt research 'brain drain'
item.description: Post-graduate education will be a significant focus of government plans to reform universities, following the release of several papers by leading academics recommending changes to higher education

item.title: Facts force King to change his tack
item.description: The Bank of England governor reverses his views on the outlook for the economy but refuses to concede the recession reflected mistakes made at Threadneedle Street

item.title: Trigger unhappy
item.description: UK pension reform must not overshadow the need to ensure that a company cannot choose to abandon its liabilities to meet employees' benefits

item.title: Austerity must follow a stimulus
item.description: The Bank of England's governor has given backing to a fiscal stimulus. Policymakers must now set out serious plans to reassure investors about the UK
